text:
Lots of coffee. Vanilla. Lots of cinnamon. 
Cocoa powder. Dark brown. Thx patrick.

Twilight of the Idols showcases Hill Farmsteads mastery of restraint. You get whispers of the added cinnamon, vanilla, and coffee but never so much that they overstay their welcome. This near-black brew puts bright, rich, and bitter toasted grains at the fore of the mouth and finishes with slight sweetness. The vanilla and cinnamon add a subtle layer of spiciness to the brew. The mouthfeel is creamy - velvety smooth. This is some damn fine stuff.

(Thanks, Brandon! "Clownoisseur")

Bottle.

A- Tobacco, cocoa, vanilla.

A- Black color, black liquid, brown head.

T- Tobacco, char, vanilla, cinnamon, roasty.

P- Full body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish.

O- Another HF beer, another success. Borderline Imperial Porter. Also bottled on my birthday! A year and a half old. Still holding up well. Easy to drink without thinking too much about it. Nice balance of vanilla and cinnamon. Coffee is there but comes through more as an earthy roastiness. Textbook porter.

50cl Bottle shared by JulienHuxley, thanks Julien! Black colour, beige head. Aroma of soft sweet malts, roast, subtle coffee, chocolate, light fruity. Flavour is medium sweet, malty, soft and well-integrated coffee, chocolate, light fruity, light vanilla, bittersweet finish. Light to medium bodied, soft mouthfeel. Tasty porter.

2015 bottle with Borresteijn & JulienHuxley, tfs Julien. Black color. big dense beige head with good lacing. Aromas: roasty, fruity. Retronasal its fruity, a bit alcohol, coffee, less fruit in time. Flavor is moderate sweet, roasty, coffee-ish. Medium bodied. Long finish with lots of roast.

Pours a dark black color with a thin moka foam. Nose of vanilla, cinammon, caramel malts, undertones of moka coffee, a bit of chocolate. Body is really thick and smooth, texture is creamy. Theres not too much harshness, carbonation or bitterness in this one. It really goes down easy. Excellent porter!

Pitch black pour with tan head... Aroma of cinnamon, roasted malts, hint of vanilla... Flavor is chocolate, nuts, cocoa powder, cinnamon and light pepper, finishes really mellow and mild, not much bitterness, notes of vanilla, silky mouthfeel, really enjoyable porter

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. HFD #19 Bardzo fajny parterowy charakter, dużo kawy i wanilii, bardzo dobra pijalność.

Thanks J! Pours a very dark brown with a rich tan head. The smell is coffee, herbal spice, chili? The taste is coffee, rich roasted malt, chili, ending dry and roasty. Medium in body with the typical elegant HF carbonation. Luxurious.

Une bière noire, à grande carbonatation, avec une couleur fort opaque. Au nez, cest très torréfié, avec des odeurs prévalantes de café et de cacao, rappelant peut-être un peu plus un stout quun porter. Au goût, le café dominé également, avec un petit goût sucré que jattribue au sucre dorge et à la mélasse. Pour un porter, on sattendrait peut-être à plus complexe, avec beaucoup de café. Le corps est bien calibré, présent mais pas trop lourd, crémeux, rappelant un millk stout. La bière nest peut-être pas ultra originale mais fait bien le travail.

Bottle shared by Joel. Poured a pitch black medium to thicker density u derived a smaller tight foamy deep mocha head. Aroma/ flavor of coffee, cinnamon, dark chocolate, burnt toast, vanilla beans. Fuller body with softer carbonation and a chalky mouthfeel. Nice

Apparence : Pas totalement noire, carbonatation moyenne, beau col brun ayant une bonne rétention et une dentelle intéressante sur le verre. 
Nez : Grains rôtis plein le nez en première impression. On note par la suite le café (bien rôti) et un peu de vanille qui vient tenter de balancer les notes grillées. 
Goût : Malt rôti, café, touche de vanille et de chocolat. Peu sucrée et peu amère, ce dernier aspect se pointant surtout en finale avec une touche épicée que jattribue à la cannelle. 
Sensation : Corps moyen à mince, longueur moyenne en bouche effervescence plutôt faible. 
Bref : On a ici droit à une bière sans contredit dominée par les notes rôties et ce, autant au nez quen bouche. Lapport de la vanille ici, quoiquintéressant, est peut-être trop discret pour empêcher le malt et le café déclipser plusieurs subtilités que lon pourrait peut-être trouver dans ce liquide. La cannelle, qui na pas figuré au rendez-vous dun point de vue gustatif, se manifeste par un côté épicé qui vient tout de même nous épargner dune finale redondante sur les tons de grillé. Facile à boire, elle remplit son rôle de Porter, malgré un taux dalcool plus élevé que ce quon retrouve traditionnellement. Agréable, mais pas renversante.

Hunted by Sergey; 7.2% ABV; 10.06.16Black color; brown compact head. Wonderful aroma, coffee, intense, velvety. Dry but extremely smooth; very good flavor of cocoa, chocolate, coffee, a bit spicy; roasty, velvety. Balanced and elegant.Wonderful.

Tasting at Alexs. 500ml, bottled on 06-Oct-2016 (thx, Hugo V.!). Pours an almost black with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, some dark fruits. Taste is coffee, some berry notes, roasted malt. Despit I couldnt find any vanilla presence, this beer is really good.
Bottle - Dark roast and coffee notes with a touch of spicy cinnamon. Jet black brown with a decent light brown head. Dark roast malts with some cinnamon and coffee notes. Spicy and decent finish.

Poured into a Hill Farmstead becher pint glass.
The appearance was a dark brown mostly close to black color with a great two finger foamy off white to tan head. Mild lacing roaming all around the glass.
The aroma took on a great amount of roasty to smooth sweet cocoa to coffee great bitterness. Subtle cinnamon, but super low key, really, it is. Some vanilla bean.
The flavor rides on the smoothness of the sweet to roasty cocoa to coffee bean. Subtle riding bitter to a smooth roasty coffee aftertaste sliding on into the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium like a good American styled porter should sit. Carbonation felt exactly right for what it should be.
Overall, a very well done porter that I would have again.

Bottle with MF666. Black with a medium sized light brown head with fine retention and lace. Rich roasted malt, vanilla, light wood, charcoal and dark chocolate. Full body, low sweetness, medium bitter with light warming alcohol. Long finish. Good.
On tap at Big Fattys. Pours black with a tan head. Roasted malt aroma with chocolate ,coffee, and faint cinnamon. Flavor is roasted malt up front with cocoa,coffee, vanilla, and a hint of cinnamon.
Pours black with brown head. A strong coffee and roasted malt aroma. A smooth body with a chocolate, milky coffee, and roasted malt taste. Sweet chocolate and lingering roasted malt aftertaste.
world class porter. looks great and taste great. lots of lace. very smooth. on tap at blackpub.

A very good holiday Porter. Pours a deep brown-black with a thick tan head. Smells of vanilla, cinnamon and chocolate. Taste is very thick, with lots of cinnamon upfront, followed by vanilla, cola chocolate and coffee. Vanilla sticks around for the aftertaste. Had on tap at Mad Taco in Vermont.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle thanks to Julien. Pours jet black smooth with a light foamy mocha almost marshmallow head. Smells of light chocolate, vanilla cocoa, roasted coffee beans and slightly boozy finish on the aroma. Tastes roasty, sweet, and chocolatey with a great vanilla smoothness and finish. Very, very smooth in comparison to other dark beers Ive had. Nice light mouthfeel, not too carbonated at all. Great, great porter. Another Banger by Hill Farmstead. Love it.

(On tap @ Warpigs HF Day, Copenhagen, May 12 2016) Pours black with a decent sized pale tan head of loose foam with lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, moderately roasted malts, vanilla, light coffee, cinnamon slight and almost woody. Flavour is dark chocolate semi-sweet core, vanilla, light coffee, fairly high roast, spicy cinnamon hints to it with slight anise tone. Finish is rather dry and slightly dusty with fairly high bitter notes from roast and coffee with a touch of hops. Light to medium body for style, soft creamy carbonation. Smooth and not completely dominated by the adjuncts, well balanced, a very nice drinkable porter.

Bottle from PhillyCraft. Thank Vin! It pours a dark brown color with a tall, creamy tan head. The aroma is nice with some creamy coffee, treacle and hints of tobacco. The flavor has lots of tobacco leaf, hints of smoke, coffee and fig. Im not really getting the vanilla or cinnamon, but Im digging the tobacco leaf dankness along with a rich, roasted chocolaty body. Very smooth and creamy on the palate. Im thinking maybe some late boil Columbus hops in this one? No matter...its pretty tasty and interesting.

Bottle: Poured a black color porter with a nice large brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt with nice floral coffee notes with some vanilla undertones. Taste is a great mix of vanilla undertones with some floral coffee notes with some light roasted malt and subtle residual sugar notes are also discernable. Body is about average but has a nice creamy texture with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. Very flavorful with great attenuation. Probably one of the best example of the style Ive had the chance to drink.

Thanks Huhzubendah for sharing the bottle! Poured into a snifter showing coffee rims with a finger of latte foam. 

The nose shows a moderately intense mix of vanilla and coffee that come together to make a light latte nose. 

The palate is fully carbonated and light bodied - perfect porter style. Flavors are vanilla forward with moderately intense roasted coffee and malt notes on mid palate ending on a light black coffee bitterness.

On tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. HF tap takeover. Pours dark brown with moderate tan head. Roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, just the right amount of sweetness, dry and bitter finish. Oily, full bodied. Fantastic. Somehow I preferred this to Everett.
Sample @ Hill Farmstead Tap Takeover, Warpigs. Dark brown body with a small offwhite head. Roased malt, milk chocolate, vanilla, liquorice notes, coffee, spices.

Hill Farmestad tap takeover at Warpigs may 12th 2016. Black body with a tiny beige head. Roasty aroma with licorice, cocoa and herbs. Taste is mild fruity, strong coffee, silky sweet vanilla, light cinnamon, robust bitterness. Huge roast and chocolate finish with a smooth espresso aftertaste. Nice!
Malziger, hefig gewürziger Antrunk mit leichter Süße. Dabei beinhaltet die Süße Vanillenoten, die Kaffeenoten passen weniger zur Süße. Vollmundig, steigend nach Kaffee, süffig. Gut. 11/10/11/12/12/11

500 mL bottle shared by Chris with Doug, Ryan, and I. The pour is a darker brown color with a nice mahogany hue and a thicker tan head that falls down leaving a pretty good lace. The aroma is very roasty right up front. There is a light coffee, a slight hint of vanilla and a definite milkiness to this. There is a light chocolate there, more of a cocoa powder that seems to drown out the vanilla. The flavor is similar. Very roasty with a lactose sweetness. There is a light chocolate, maybe a little caramel, but the vanilla just isnt prominent at all. The mouth feel is surprisingly thin, but the carbonation helps it seem thicker than it really is. The aftertaste is light coffee, and a roasty lactose finish. Its an interesting beer, but I definitely wish there was more vanilla.

Draught @ [ Hill Farmsted Tape Take Over ] - Warpigs Brewpub, Flaesketorvet 24, DK-1711 Copenhagen, Denmark. [ As Hill Farmstead Twilight Whole Sale ].Clear dark brown color with a small to average, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark malt, roasted, chocolate, caramel, moderate hoppy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, sweet malt, chocolate, dark malt, dry, light wood. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20160512]

Dark brown color with some light penetration on the edges. Creamy tan head that sheets over the top. Spearmint and coffee nose. Slight vanilla finish. Medium mouthfeel. Slight farmhouse tartness. Very good

Fad. Selv på en varm sommerdag hvor man craver IPA er dette en fornem øl. Enorm fylde med den karakteristiske portersødme gør at man snildt kan tage en nr 2. Lidt kaffe men ikke meget. Fornem huling. Dejlig øl.
On draft in Copenhagen (Mikkeller Viktoriagade). Creamy, with notes of raisin, lactose. Great body and superbly balanced. I really got on with this one.
On tap at Warpigs. Black with tan head. Aroma has roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, caramel and coffee. Taste is medium sweet with similar notes, long roasted coffee choclate finish

Bottle shared in Rome, outside of Frankenfest 2016. Creamy tan foam, lacing on rich brown-black. Bitter licorice, sharp sip. Bitter and a touch of alcohol. Rich, creamy, velvety. Strange play of fruit, vanilla and coffee. ice beer, elegant, but not my profile.

[ bottle ][ 1.5oz ][ @Tasting ][ $ ? ][ schnapps snifter ][ 01.09.15 ] black, thick cream head. cocoa dust nose, metallic carbonation in the nose. Inky body, anise with plenty of dark chocolate, thin body with way low carbonation, finishes rich and cake-like, very dessert esque. Way too thin but profile is awesome.
Tap Black colour with small beige head.Aroma is mild spicey of cinnamon and vanilla with also flavor of chocolate and caramel,good roasted with smooth mouth feels and light coffee flavor aswell.

Draft. A black beer with a huge lazing brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, and alcohol, leading to a dry roasted finish.
pour black with a small tan head. liqurish aroma, with coffee and vanilla notes, soft bitter taste. medium bodied, light carbonated, light creamy,

Tap @ Mikkeller Aarhus. Aroma of oak(!), some vanilla, chocolate, coffee. Black colour with tan head, not lasting. Moderate malt bitter, smooth, coffee. Full body, oily smooth feel, chocolate bitter finish.

Bottled 11/15/15 and drunk 5/22/16, shared by AdamC, thanks!Dark ebony with some muted mahogany hues on the edges. Seemingly good clarity with a tan head atop that is medium-sized and fades quickly to cover.Vanilla and cinnamon are easily picked out of the nose, as a dark chocolate backdrop keeps things "dry" and very porter-like. I honestly get more house yeast character than anything, and thankfully, the coffee is nice and restrained, adding only a light amount of roast. Biscuity, chocolate-laden malts linger, with more cinnamon spiciness and no alcohol or flaw.Lots of cinnamon in the flavor, drying things out considerably, with spicy vanilla quite apparent as well. Dark chocolate, very light roast, bits of prune/plum and very low sweetness on top of a medium-light body with low carbonation. Its drinkable and nicely attenuated with no forceful malt sweetness or alcohol, but I could do with less cinnamon and probably less vanilla, even granting that this is a holiday spiced porter. Otherwise, nicely done and surprisingly light.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Pitch black colored with a medium sized beige head.
Roasted aroma of caramel, chocolate, coffee and vanilla.
Roasted flavor of caramel and coffee with notes of vanilla and hops.
Roasted finish.

duft: svag krydret svag ristet malt
smag ristet chokolade svag krydret kakao

Tap. Black body with an average fluffy, beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, coffee, vanilla and cinnamon. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry with bitter notes. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. An excellent Porter. 🌟🌟🌟🌟

[5/12/16] Draught at Warpigs in Copenhagen. Black. Big chocolate and cocoa aroma. Roasty bittersweet flavor with chocolate, cocoa, some coffee, a bit of licorice, and a bitter finish. Full-bodied. Really good.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar. Low fluffy and quickly disappearing light brown head. Pitch black body. Sweet wineous vanilla coffee cocoa atoma and flavor. Little hops bitterness, low caronation, long sweet finish.

Draught @ Hill Farmstead Day - Warpigs Brewpub, København
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, caramel and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long roasted, chocolate, coffee and vanilla finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

From tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Black color with beige head. Roasted malty aroma, chocolate, caramel, coffee, licorice, light spicy. Sweet and bitter taste. Medium oily silky body with soft carbonation.
On tap at Warpigs, pre-CBC. Pitch black with an espresso head. Tons of chocolate in the nose and taste, soft chocolate and a bit of spice. Really nice.
Sample at Warpigs during the HF event. Roasted smell with chocolate and dark malts. Similar taste with caramel. Very tasty and roasted. A bit too light body. Spritsy.

Draught @ Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, sweetness, caramel, nuts, wood, chocolate, light alcohol. Flavor is light sweet, rich malty, caramel, cocoa, dark chocolate, some alcohol. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, light sweet finish with warming alcohol. 120516
Tap at Warpigs, Copenhagen. Colour is dark with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Dry.

Draught @ Hill Farmstead Day, Warpigs, Copenhagen. Pours pitch black with a smooth head. Aroma of roasty malts, cinnamon, spices, chocolate and coffee. Taste is smooth, slightly roasty and spicy with hints of cinnamon, rye and chocolate. Finish is smooth, slightly roasty and spicy with some grainy notes, rye and chocolate. Interesting.

Pours dark with minimal head 
Aromas of spices, vanilla, coffee, caramel, muscavado 
Taste has notes of coffee, milk chocolate, almonds, muscavado, dried fruits
Tap @Warpigs. Black, small beige head. Aroma has has roasted malt, dark sugar and coffee. Coffee and caramel flavour, boozy but very wellbalanced, good.

Pours black with a low tan head. Aromas of chocolate, lactose, brown sugar, roasted nuts, roasted malt. Taste is toasted and somewhat bitter with perfectly balanced sweet caramel notes. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation.

12.05.2016, tap @ Warpigs:
Nice light brown creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly rich, dark malts, dark sugar, coffee, mild grassy chillies, minerals, licorice, caramel, grass. Taste is slightly rich and dry, dark malts, hops, espresso, dark sugar, licorice, grass, minerals, bark, burnt caramel. Medium bitterness, slightly dry mouthfeel. Nice.

Draught. Black coloured. Dense light brown head. Aroma. Coffee, smoke, cocoa, liqourice. Flavour. Cocoa, roast, liqourice, smoke, spice, coffee. Medium to full bodied. Ends roasted bitter and coffeedense

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at warpigs. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and vanilla. Notes of cinnamon. The flavours starts sweet but finish medium bitter with long duration, peppery. The body is full and the texture is creamy. Nice

From tap at Warpigs, Hill Farmstead Day. Its a black beer with a creamy beige head. Loads of coffee in the aroma along with fine roasted malts. Light cinnamon and licorice. Very nice roasted flavor with a great coffee punch. Vanilla and light cinnamon.
On tap at Warpigs. Black with a small off-white head. Aroma of licorice and toffee with a spicy touch. Sweet, roasted flavour with licorice, coffee and chocolate and a light touch of ash.

Cocoa powder on nose, chocolate, malts. Med bodied, long finish. Lots of cocoa, bit dry, slight bready. Nice.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Tap at warpigs. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of licorice, toffee, roast, light hops, light fudge notes. Taste is heavy sweet, roast, licorice choko. Very good.

Tap@ warpigs. Pours near black with a thin off white head. Nutty, dark chocolate, nutella like creamy nutty aroma. Flavor has dark roasted coffee, ashy notes, dark dark chocolate / cocoa powder, plummy finish. Dry, hoppy finish. Complex.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2016 Bottle, by way of trade with Rich182. Huge thanks, Rich. Clear, dark, chestnut brown. Thin, dense, sticky, viscous, tan head. Aroma of light roast coffee. Soft, gingery spice. Some cocoa. Some fruity chocolate. Subtle cinnamon. Maybe wouldnt have picked it up if I wasnt looking for it? Soft, fruity tang behind all that. Whatever, it smells great. Taste is light, tangy bitter. Soft, vanilla sweetness on the lips. Smooth, airy palate. Very easy drinking. Fruity, vinous, cocoa bitter finish. Nice one.

500 ml. bottle sampled @ Hopishop #3. 11.18.15. Pours black syrup with no head; nose is thick molasses, umami roast, syrup, licorice, low coffee & sadly no vanilla or cinnamon. Taste is roasted coffee, syrup, umami, basic syrup, low herbal, bitter basic malt roast, cheap syrup, low licorice, very faint hazel. Syrupy & umami. Overly umami for me, one would expect more classical sweetness from a cinnamon, vanilla & coffee porter. Yeah where is my vanilla & where is cinnamon? This might not be ubber fresh by no way should so much vanilla or cinnamon fade to nothing this quickly. Hill Farmstead is for sure a very good but the nearly religious cult of Shaun Hill worship remains lost for me. This is a decent porter, fans might argue that this is balanced, I would argue that if you brag about using cinnamon & vanilla it should be there in the taste. The more remote your brewery is, the better it supposedly is. Someone I feel like Americans try to out-hype each other.

750ml bottle shared by luttonm @FrankenBierFest (Rome). Thank you Matt! Pours deep brown with a medium cappuccino head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, lots of vanilla. Flavour is rich and complex with a rounded body, medium sweet with a good bitter end. Medium to high body, medium to low carbonation. Great one!

Bottle shared by luttonm in Rome-Italy. Grazie. Pours black color, brownish head. Nose: grounded coffee, roasted, a bit smokey. Great. Mouth: cocoa, vanilla, clean finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Dark pour with light head. Roasted, chocolate, vanilla and dark aromas. Flavors are similar, roasted, vanilla, chocolate and sweet notes.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2016 Bottle traded for some Struise vintages in Ghent, cheers Xavier! Very curious about this, seen the fact that this brewery has been hyped by beer geeks to a very large extent in recent years, more so for its saisons and IPAs perhaps, but still... Thick, dense and moussy, yellowish beige, lightly lacing head over a blackish beer with hazy but translucent chestnut brown edges. Complex aroma: a lot of beef stock and bitter chocolate, some faint shoe polish-like solvents but actually fitting in well, old blanket, salmiak, dry earth, bayleaf, subtle and hardly noticeable vanilla touch, dried nettles, white pepper, elderberry, wet leather and, after warming up, a lovely, unexpected, sweet hint of red wine or even sherry. Very umami-like onset, stewed beef and even some dried porcini, low but effective sweetishness of dried fruits, rounded and slightly oily, creamy mouthfeel with velvety texture and soft carbo, some elderberry-like sourishness underlying; caramelly malts turning immediately nutty and eventually toasted, leading to a bitter chocolatey, lightly coffeeish roasted, mouth-filling bitterness; peppery and spicy hop bitterness adds dryness while a basic roasted barley sourishness lingers and retronasally, elegant and subtle hints of vanilla and red wine appear. Technically perfect, the vanilla aspect could have been a lot more pronounced in my opinion, but instead I got unexpected sherryish or red wine-like aromas which make this altogether different from most other porters. Subtle, delicate, completely satisfying example of the style, very glad I tasted this - now on the lookout for more beers from Shaun Hill.

Draft at Fools Gold for their Hill Farmstead event, 2/20/16. 

Dark brown color. Lots of coffee and roast with a bit of spice. Vanilla sweetness balances it out a bit. Fairly rich overall, but with an easy drinkingness to it as well that just really works. Nice mix of flavors, really good feel. Just a very tasty and enjoyable beer.
Smells like coffee grounds and a bit of marshmallow. Taste is super roasty coffee with a nice aftertaste of chocolate. Medium body, medium carbonation, and low foam.

Bottle. Pours black with an ample, mocha head. Messy lacing coats the glass after a few sips, slowly receding head.becomes a soft ring around the glass. Aromas of cocoa, roasted malts, alcohol, scant vanilla. A medium bitterness that builds and lasts well into the finish, a light to light+ sweetness underneath. Mouthfeel is great. Medium bodied and creamy with soft carbonation. Some cinnamon spiciness creeps up in the finish, but it is subtle. Bitter finish.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour opaque dark brown with copper hue and large tan head. Nose milk chocolate, coco powder, light coffee. Taste starts with fleeting sweetness, then dark fruit, dark chocolate, and medium roast coffee. Light powder late palate. Nice mix of sweet and roast.

Bottle shared by a friend. Pours black with a medium tan head. Nose consisting of malt, coffee, roast and vanilla. Malty flavor giving way to creamy vanilla and dark fruit before a roasted malt finish.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2016 Bottle @ Mikkeller bar, Aarhus. Black pour with a frothy light tan head. Notes of caramel, light roast, light bitter coffee, some vanilla and light spice. A bit dull.

Rerate:
Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Aarhus. Spices and vanilla a bit more prominent this time. Nice and balanced!

This is one of the best porters Ive ever had. The mouthfeel is so full and smooth that it makes you think that it almost makes you think youre drinking a cream soda, which is really nicely amplified by the vanilla. The coffee and roasted malts play together well, and it makes for a rich, full, delightful porter -- another knockout from HF.
Dark brown pour. Big tan head. Plenty of lacing. Minerally aroma, slight coffee note. Malty sweet taste. Also slight acrid finish.

Bottle, 2yr old. Pours pitch black with big tan head. Aroma is very straight forward porter alike. Roast malts, chocolate, licorice, burnt malt. Taste is sweet, caramel, light vanilla, light spice. Creamy mouthfeel. Smooth and balanced, but boring. Dry finish.
Pours a dark brown with an off white lacing. The aroma is coffee, cinnamon and finished with a hint of vanilla.

500 ml. bottle. Pours black with a nice, fluffy tan head. Great lacing. Aroma of malt, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Didnt find any cinnamon. Nice.

This beer pours a dark brown color with a medium foamy beige head that diminishes gradually to a film. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted coffee, malt and vanilla. Medium body with flavors of espresso, roast malt, vanilla and dark chocolate. The finish is roasty with a coffee and malt aftertaste. Solid beer all around.

Bottle courtesy of the dangerous bottle share group. Black with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, notes of spices, liquorice and a little smoke. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, wood, notes of spices, little smoke, wood, medium sweet and medium bitter

Bottle thanks to Nathan Gelfam. Pours pitch black with a medium brown head. Aromas of faded coffee, tobacco, light smoky notes, sweeter notes (vanilla?), malty, roasty, chocolate, light bitter, licorice. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, bitter, licorice, light vanilla. Pretty disappointed in this :( No cinnamon left.
Nice head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, chocolate, cinnamon, coffee, hops and hasa nice bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy of the dangerous bottle share group. Thanks guys. Black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla and wood. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter. 230116

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2016 Bottle thanks to Nathan. 2 years old or so. Pours an almost Black brown with a big, fluffy, tan head. Aroma has lots of old coffee, toasted malts, tobacco, Dark chocolate, slight smoke. Taste is roasty, slight smoke, licorice, coffee, light sweet, medium bitter. AVG-High carb, slight watery body. Smager fint.
---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rerated at Mikkeller bar Aarhus. Much more spicy and overall good and fresh coffee than last time. Better, but still no masterpiece.

5 oz sample at a tasting. Pours a deep brown/black with a bubbly tan head. Aromas of coffee and cinnamon stood out to me the most. Very nice. Flavor had coffee up front, then milder notes of the cinnamon and vanilla, and some spices. Full body, slick texture, soft carbonation, and a bitter and dry finish. Very good brew.

Bottle shared by Matt at Gaucho. Pours a deep brown with a light brown head. Aromas of light coffee and vanilla not getting much cinnamon. Taste is typical HF, super soft, no flavors overpower any others. Solid and easy drinking.

Bottle at the nuplastikk returns tasting in VA. Dark brownish black with beige head. Aromas of dark fruit and chocolate. Tastes of dark chocolate, coffee, dark fruit. Medium body with a dry finish. Nice porter.
Some great roast and some chocolate. Pours black with great head and lacing. Light bittersweet finish. Creamy consistency. Good balance and well done.
From a 50 cl bottle shared at the 2016 Nuplastik is back tasting. Pours Black with a tan head. Aroma of leather. Flavors of coffee, cinnamon and vanilla. Bitter roast finish.
Aroma of light coffee, green pepper, vanilla, soy. Taste of pretty mellowed out fruity coffee, green pepper, vanilla, quite plain.
500ml bottle. Dark brown with a foamy tan head. Flavors are molasses, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, roasted cereals with fruity and spicy notes. Medium body, moderate carbonation, smooth texture.

Opaque black with a large tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, cinnamon, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste of roasted malts, vanilla beans, chocolate, light cinnamon, sweeter, light alcohol in the finish.

Tap at Jeffrey not sure why I started with a porter but delicious non the less. Lovely dark pour pour small beige head. Nose is roasted coffee beans and light vanilla. Tastes of high quality chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and espresso. Every thing is in balance and in place and lovely example.

Pours a deep down black light brown head. Aroma is roasty chocolate, smoke, coffee grounds, vanilla. Flavor is smooth sweet malt, chocolate, smoke, pine, coffee, cocoa. Med body, solid carb, well balanced.

A deep dark porter with a very thin mocha head. In aroma, loads of bitter chocolate, with coffee grind, dark fruits, molasses, alcohol warmth, very nice. In mouth, a nice bitter sweet chocolate with coffee grind, musty character, light vanilla notes, nice and smooth. Bottle at Montréal Xmas gathering 2015.

Bottle shared at the 10th Annual Epic & Unusual Beer Tasting, 11/29/15. Dark brown, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate. spice. The taste is roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla, dark fruit. Medium bodied, smooth.

Bottle shared. Pours black with a big beige head. Aroma of milk chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, coffee, fudge, a little dark fruits, toffee and malt. Flavour is light heavy sweet and light moderate bitter. Medium to full bodied with light carbonation.

Dark brown in color. Some lasting light caramel head. Im a little stuffy but Im getting the coffee and cinnamon. Similar flavors - no vanilla coming through unfortunately. Nice flavor. Missing the promise of vanilla.

Un liquide brun foncé dégusté en compagnie de Mademoiselle Irina. Bien que mince, le liquide saccroche bien au verre et y dépose de jolies lacings. Nez de forte torréfaction, dépices sèches et de café. En bouche je note du poivron vert, du café fort mais très peu de la cannelle et de la vanille à laquelle je mattendais. Le liquide est sec et mince. Le grain de café entier et grillé occupe trop despace pour que je puisse apprécier la douceur de la vanille à sa juste valeur. Pas mauvais mais loin dêtre excellent.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Bottle. Pours dark clear black, small tan head, dissipates fairly quickly, some lacing. Aroma is cocoa, vanilla, coffee, ashtray. Flavor is light plus sweet, light bitter, coffee, cocoa, hints of cinnamon. Lots of vanilla n the mouth, touch of bourbon or whiskey. Medium body, a bit acidic.
Bottle poured black iced coffee with a beige head thin lacing. Aromas of cocoa, vanilla, roasted malt, and coffee. Flavor is initially mild bitter with a sweet chocolate finish. Yum.

500 mL bottle. Originally reviewed 5/4/2013.

Black with a khaki head. Chunky bubbles unbalanced around the edge. Slightly transparent at the edges.

Smell has lots of vanilla. Coffee, but not the most interesting or intense coffee flavor. Sweet malt and some roast.

Taste is still lots of vanilla. Chocolate and coffee. Lacking the roast Id like from it. Bitter chocolate and a slight herbal character. Tastes like spices in the finish.

Slick and chewy for its size. Medium carbonation.

Lots of vanilla. Needs more roast. Good without being Hill Farmsteads best beer.

Bottle shared at The Cads 10 year get together. 29/03/2015. Thanks to my HF pusher Leighton. Pure black / caramel brown coloured pour with a lasting creamy tan head. Aroma is earthy, woody, coffee beans, little coco and toasted cocoonut. Flacour is composed of toasted coconut, coco powder, little plumy berry. Palate is airy carbonation, dry and crisp. Good stuff.

Bottle at the Cads 10th Anniversary bash, big thanks to Leighton my HF stockist, 29/03/15. 
Light black with a big old tan covering.
Nose is roast malt, coffee, spice, chocolate, dark toffee, charr.
Taste comprises roast malt, coffee, molasses, charr, spice, cocoa powder, dark malts, toffee.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, semi drying close.
Xolid porter.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle @ The Cads 10yr Shindig. Thanks to Leighton. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocolate aroma. Roasted malty coffee and chocolate flavor with weak hints of vanilla. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocolate finish.

Bottle shared at The Cads 10 Year Ratebeer Anniversary session care of the alway generous Leighton. Colour is opaque dark brown, tan head. Nose is coffee rich, nice lingering dark chocolate, touch of soft sourness, barrel aged wood. taste is Cocoa, dark chocolate, barrel aged woodiness. Its subtle sophisticated soft delicate. Burnt malts. On the finish theres some nice lingering chocolate and cocoa.

75cl bottle shared at The Cads 10yr anniversary celebration at CBC Clerkenwell, London. Once again major thanks to Leighton for the HF fix. It pours a dark brown color with a foamy brown head. Aroma is chocolate and espresso, with roasted malts and light tangyness. Taste is quite dry with dark chocolate, coffee beans powder, roasted wood and minerals. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Good overall.

Bottle share at the Cads 10 year at CBC Clerkenwell. Thanks to Leighton, I think. Black, small foamy brown head, light lacing. Aroma is coffee and chocolate syrup. Body is medium, foamy, low carbonation. Taste is coffee, rounded malts, chocolate, tangy dry finish. Definitely a well executed porter.
Bottle at Toms 10 yr anniversary. Chocolate woody aroma. Decent chocolate. Its ok a bit thin over carbonated harsh om the finish.

Black colour, tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, caramel, red fruit, vanilla. Sweet chocolate flavour, vanilla, coffee. Finish coffee, vanilla and chocolate.(from 66cL bottle @ Kamiels place. Thanks for sharing!)

Bottle (50cl): Shared with Iluvatarmilan and Martinus: Served in a Chouffe glass at 14 degrees Celsius:
Big beige light brown head black beer.
Aromas of malt roast, light chocolate, dust, light vanilla, herbal roast...
Flavours of malt roast, coffee, bitters, light coffee roast, light mocha...
Aftertaste is a mix of roast, coffee, bitters...
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Fall/Winter 2012 Bottling
From notes. Tasted on 12/12/12 from a capped 500mL bottle with Curtis, and the Nashville crew. Pours dark brown with a bit of red velvet tint, and a thin tan head that leaves very thin lace. The nose is dark and roasted with toasted cocoa nibs, coffee, dark chocolate, and plenty of vanilla. The flavor is quite dry and bitter with loads of natural vanilla, and all of the same bitter dark, roasted and toasted notes, and just a touch of spicy cinnamon poking through. The body is full with just lighter than average carbonation and a long roasted bitter coffee and vanilla finish.

[6138-20140121] Bottle. Metallic rusty roasty paper grains aroma has an odd fruity note. Cola black body with a quick foamy tan head. Milk chocolate Tootsie Roll roasted coffee flavour has a long lingering aftertaste. Full body has a bitter full bite. Lovely. (8/4/9/4/16) 4.1
(c/o blankboy, w/ him, HogTownHarry, jercraigs)

From notes taken during a tasting a couple weeks back. 
Aroma has a lot of coffee character but it has started to turn vegetal, especially as it mixes with the cinnamon. Light vanilla note with moderate roast and faint chocolate. 
Pours black with dark brown hues and a nice dark tan head. 
Flavor is rather peppery with light coffee and vanilla notes. Medium light roast notes with light chocolate and lighter tobacco and leather. Not much cinnamon. Moderate bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, not a great coffee character. Not sure what batch this bottle was from but the coffee had turned very vegetal and peppery. Other adjuncts dont really come through much.

Thanks Steasy66 for the bottle! Peppry, malty, caramel, bit medicine in nose.
Taste is watery, malt, peppers.

Pours a very dark brown almost black with khaki colored head. Coffee, cinnamon, vanilla, and roastjavascript: RadioSel(overall,16);ed malt on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with a roasted vanilla malt note.
At tall Matts house with Matt, Matt, garrett, and respective chicks. Pours dark dark brown. Aroma is oats, light roasted malt, light, coffee. Taste is tasty chocolate, roasty vanilla.

Thnx to steacy 
Pours black, small grey head. Smell is peppers, bit roasty. 
Taste is roasted malts. Thin mouthfeel. Some vanilla sharpness (very different than oak vanilla) ok, but lacks a good mouthfeel.
shared with a buddy. not sure if maybe i got an old bottle or one that had been under light. had weird funky flavor, not in a good way.

How: Bottle.
Where: From a trade.
Appearance: Dark brown colour with a beige head.
Aroma: Roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, coffee.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: Coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, some vanilla.
Tasted like pennies. Very very thin mouthfeel. Aroma was just off too. Didn't like it one bit.

Bottle: Relatively fresh bottle, somewhere around 7-8 months old. Deep, nearly black body with a tan-mocha foam that builds up quickly & diminishes just as fast to a thin film & chunky collar. Big tannic aroma, lots of wet & sharp oak. Why? This is not even barrel aged... Where is this woodiness coming from? Mildly tart plum & black cherry spread over a bed of roasted cocoa beans, light coffee grounds, & faint milk chocolate. The tart dark fruitiness doesnt carry over to the palate (which is good, I assume), & theres only a small hint of anise & raisin. The flavor is most a pile of dry cocoa beans, blackened malt just shy of charred status, light vanilla bean, & a touch of roasted coffee beans; not quite Italian roast, but maybe a touch more than French. I was expecting a sweeter porter, but this is definitely more kiltered to the roasty side of things. Very faint cinnamon character throughout. VERY mild. Perhaps that was the first adjunct to bite the dust. Thin-ish mouth feel, even for a "porter". Im sick of that excuse... Porters can have voluptuousness, too. Its a good beer, but its far from great. Near the bottom rungs of my HF favorites, for sure. This is one Id LOVE to have fresh from the tap, though, just to compare.

16.9 oz bottle. Dark brown with a clumpy tan head. Nose is cocoa, hay, clay and coffee with light caramel and vanilla. Soft and silky, melt in the mouth, finishing like a coffee. Taste is perfectly balanced caramel, vanilla and coffee with hints of chocolate and citrus. Ive had similar brews but never so refined. Must be something in the water.
smells of vanilla and cinnamon, pours very dark with minimal brown head, sweet multiple layer taste that finishes smooth, full bodied with low carbonation. outstanding porter this brewery is sick
Une bouteille de la série Nietzsche. Un liquide brun foncée. Un nez qui ma semblé dur à percer avec cet iode. Une bouche agréable par sa texture avec des notes de chocolats et de vanille.

Dark brown with a good brown head. Aroma is green bell pepper, vegetables, hint of coffee. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel, slightly vegetal on the palate. Flavour is green bell pepper, some dark fruit.

Bottle thanks to Russell. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roasted nuts, dark chocolate, and wood. Thin mouthfeel with light roast, coffee bean, dark chocolate and lingering bitterness. Good.

Nov 2013 bottle thanks to my local group for sharing. Opaque black pour with very little head. Aromas are vanilla, roasted coffee, chocolate syrup, cinnamon, and tobacco. Smooth taste. Mostly coffee and vanilla with hints of spices and cocoa. Very nice porter.

Sampled under less than ideal circumstances No head left on fully opaque brown beer; Sweetish-roasted nose; wafts of spices - mainly cinnamon - and black chocolate. Sweet-bitterish chocolate, and very dry. Not much impact from the spices, not even the cinnamon, though the dry bitterness hints effectively at barkspices. Dried berries, velvet. Hints of vanilla in the finish. Medium bodied, very slick & dry, nearly oily. Carbonation gone in the sample. The subdued spices are a bad and a plus: restraint is good, but theres also a bit lack of character.  Many thanks to Mathieu!< /I>

50 cl avec la date suivante : 11/2013. La robe est bien brune. La petite tête se transforme rapidement en anneau plutôt chétif. Le nez est plutôt épicé et complexe. Outre la cannelle, voici des parfums de piment ou de poivron. La base maltée noire apporte des effluves de chocolat. Une pointe de vanille saffirme davantage lorsque le liquide se tempère. Les saveurs sont plutôt douces et mélangent chocolat au lait, épices, caramel et acidité des grains rôtis. En bouche, le liquide est plutôt mince et sa texture est à la limite crémeuse. En finale, la cannelle picote ma langue qui reste longuement sucrée. Merci à czar pour la bouteille.

Bottle at home, shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: pitch black beer, small unstable beige head.
NOSE: chocolate, coffee, vanilla, mocha, wood, little watery, light in alcohol.
TASTE: lots of taste, vanilla, chocolate, mocha, slight alcohol, wood, some liquorice.

With the crew and paired with BoT. Big nice aroma with roasty malt and bittersweet coffee. Perfect aroma score. Other than an ipa the aroma has never gotten a 10 from me I dont think. Complex and smooth. Another seriously complex and subtle beer here.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2014 Recd in a trade and shared with the crew. Nice vanilla, subtle coffee, robust malt character, a bit spicy from the cinnamon. All in all this is just a really well crafted beer. Nothing was overpowering and superbly balanced throughout.

500 ml bottle. Thanks Jeremy for sharing. Cinnamon is the strongest flavor, but everything is pretty subtitle and muted. Definitely has a chriaas stout taste to it. Kinda boring, which is pretty typical for all the HF stouts and porters. The IPAs they make are phenomenal, I get why people like the sourish saisons, but the dark beers are just bland.

Pours dark brown with a large frothy head. The mouthfeel is on the lighter side initially but settles a little thicker after a while. The nose has coffee first off.. Then roasted malts and maybe coke (or pepsi) a tiny bit of choolate as well perhaps. The taste is sweetish but it ticks all the porter boxes. Nice malty aftertaste with a slightly bitter finish.

Pour is dark brow, with a huge bubbly light tan head. 
Aroma of coffee, bitter chocolate, slightly roasted malts, faint hints of smoke, and hints of vanilla. Taste is somewhat bitter, but pretty well balanced. Really great porter imo. 
Medium bodied, with a lively carbonation. Thanks a lot to Mr. BoogyChillin for sending this out.

Bottle. Pours black with creme colored head that lingers. Smells of chocolate with super smooth vanilla. Excellent stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bouteille 500 mL. Nez marqué par la vanille, supporté par le grain rôti. Bouche crémeuse, chocolat au lait avec une bonne présence de vanille, grains grillés et amertume de café en milieu de bouche et en finale. Je ne suis normalement pas un grand amateur de bières à la vanille, mais celle-ci est un belle ambassadrice du style.

Near pitch black, small head. Big roasty aroma, lots of dark chocolate with coffee, vanilla in the background. Big taste, chocolate gives way to vanilla sweetness, coffee bitterness, very lit smoke and spiciness. Medium body soft carbonation.

500ml bottle. 
Black pour, small brown head. Aroma of rich, dark, roasted coffee, roasted malts, soy, and some wood, with what i can only describe as hot pepper aroma, minus the heat, must be the cinnamon. Very soft carb, mouth feel is a little thinner that expected. The finish is woody, and herbal. Coffee and roasted malts linger and are very pleasant, bitterness is medium to low. A nice porter, but im thinking this might have fallen into the hill farmstead hype machine.

Bottle (7,2% ABV). An opaque black beer, with a large, frothy, fully lasting brown head. The aroma is moderately to heavily malty (coffee, roasted grain, chocolate, caramel), lightly hoppy (grapefruit), with notes of cinnamon, some vanilla and berries. The flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, velvety texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, pretty dry and long finish with moderate bitterness, very lightly alcoholic. It feels really clean with pure, all but artificial flavors. Nicely dry and drinkable. Im impressed, although not as much as with their Saisons.

Bottle. Opaque black liquid with small to medium light tan head. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, bread, biscuit, pumpernickel, dried fruit, wood and orange peel. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of chocolate, bread, biscuit, vanilla and pumpernickel. Medium bodied with low to medium carbonation. Really nice.

On draft at the brewery. Thick and oily pour into the tasting glass. Aroma of licorice, chocolate, burnt wood. Taste is all of that plus stewed dark fruit and a very dry finish. Nice big chewy porter, this makes me wonder where the line is between a porter like this and a stout.

Thanks to Brent for sharing this one at a recent tasting! Dark brown pour. Aroma: chocolate, coffee, spice, and that sort of fruity astringency that I often describe as "tangy." Somewhat herbal. Lots of spice here ... from the aroma and the taste I really didnt expect this to be a porter. Moderately sweet, minimal bitter finish. Light-medium body. Overall: Suprisingly "meh" overall. I would not call this the coming of the uber-beer.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2014 2014-01-21. Black body with a nice tan head. 3+ Aroma is lightly chalky, notes of moderate roast and a tiny whisper of smoke. The flavour is interesting, lightly roasty with sort of an odd smokey or peaty not quite vegetation like overtones. Something I cant place but that I dont entirely like the way it presents itself with the coffee roast - I decide it is likely the vanilla based on the label description. Smooth avg plus bodied palate, soft carbonation. A nice beer that does not suit me unfortunately. Bottle shared by Blankboy
Delicious porter from Hill Farmstead. I wish the bitter coffee was more muted and the vanilla more pronounced.

[My bottle (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel -- c/o Glouglouburp] Pours a very dark brown with red hues and an average size diminishing frothy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, a hint of peat, leafy hops and some light lactic notes. Flavour of leafy hops, roasted malt, vanilla, chocolate, a bit of mint and an average bitter finish. Medium bodied, slightly creamy mouthfeel. Really good stuff.

I got this in a 500ml bottle in a trade. Shared with some friends at a mini-tasting.

Its hard for me to find fault with this beer. I hate to use the generic term "balanced" but it applies very well here. Its an excellent and very smooth porter. You get the coffee, vanilla and cinnamon notes in perfect harmony. Not one flavor dominates over the other. This is one of the best beers Ive had.

Draft @ BlackBack Fly Shop. HFS snifter shows deep brown color with lasting thin white ring of head. Aroma starts of deep roasted malts followed by vanilla bean and burnt coffee grounds. The flavor follows with the vanilla bean and cinnamon integrated well throughout the sip. The body is on the fuller side for the style with a creamy texture. Delicious, nothing short of awesome.

Bottle. A loud and forceful bottle cap almost flee off. Poured into a duvel glass. Huge light brown head. Moderate coffe and dark chocolate in the nose. Not much vanilla. Flavor is similar with more chocolate and coffee. Really not seeing any sign of vanilla or cinnamon at all. Overall its not a bad porter but there isnt anything that great or complex about it.

On tap at the Black Back: Pours dark brown with a cream colored head. Vanilla, roasted malt on the nose. Flavor is vanilla, coffee, cinnamon. Malty goodness but not overwhelmingly sweet. Smooth finish, sticks to the mouth, full bodied. Awesome beer.
Growler. 75cl. Pours black with a creamy head. Mild cinnamon, roast, chocolate and coffee. Smooth and silky. Bitter roasted finish. Balanced and not overdone. Very drinkable.
Draft at Black Back pub. Waterbury VT. Amazing porter, fuller bodied thing of beauty. Chocolate, coffee, lots of roasted maltiness. Full mouthfeel. Absolutely delicious

Pours a nice dark brown with a small brown head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is of roasted grains, spices and a little bit of green pepper. It feels really fresh. Taste is only lightly sweet with roasted malt flavors (and also that slight green pepper but it isnt disturbing). Nice sweet and vanilla finish. Body is medium, carbonation level enhancing the smoothness impression. Quite elegant, moreso than I remember from our last encounter.

Bottled 2012-13 winter. Its relatively fresh is what Im saying.

Its black with a nice solid sheet of tan foam. Smells nice, coffee, cocoa, rich toasted graham crackers, bits of burnt toffee and a good dose of vanilla - but not overbearing. Flavor is rich with the tone of the nose and a little hint of pepper and almost a waxy crayon note. The bitterness is well matched with rich dark gooey chocolates and a little bit of dust. Full and smooth body with low carb and an off dry, but mucous producing finish. Nearly perfect mouthfeel for my money. nice beer as usual.

Growler. Heavy chocolate malty nose with a light vinous and vinegar tone, some coffee, and touch of cinnamon. Pours a dark reddish-brown. Light vanilla and just the right amount of cinnamon with some earthy coffee on the back end. Dry, woody spiced finish. Good stuff.

2L growler purchased 10/23. Pours dark brown with small head. Nose is coffee, cocoa, faint spices. Mouthfeel is silky smooth. Taste is subtle coffee, cream, roasty, some spices. Finish is medium bitterness with nice creamy coffee, some milk chocolate, notes of spices and cinnamon, some sweetness. So delicious.
no bullshit inane bloviation could add anything else to the discussion of descriptions of this beer.

Thanks Jason for sharing! Super carbonated when opened, sits black with a profuse fizzy tan head. Nose shows coffee and a touch of vanilla and wonderfully nuanced dark grain notes. Hard to get much out of the flavor due to the excessive carbonation. Some cacao and coffee with bitter dark grain but I feel like the more delicate compounds are lost in the maelstrom of carbonation.
Bottle tasting with Kaufmanised; dark brown pour with substantial creamy beige head, big coffee aroma, coffee taste and cocoa some earthy hop action, some nutty action and maybe a hint of vanilla.
Black, tan head. Nose is some light roast, like cocoa, a hint of vanilla, some nutmeg. Tastes as it smells. Smooth medium body. Everything is so well integrated, very clean.

Bottle courtesy of Joel. Pours a deep, murky brown body with thin mocha head/lacing. Aroma is vanilla, nuts, yeast and espresso roast. Mouthfeel is medium and very nicely balanced with notes of espresso, vanilla, nutmeg, cinnamon and spice. Very nice porter.
Bottle shared by GOTC. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of cinnamon, nutmeg, roast chocolate malt, roast coffee and vanilla. Medium body.
Shared with timfoolery. Roasty malt, vanilla, a touch of cinnamon, and some coffee. Good beer.

Bottle. Pour is dark brown with a smallish tan head. Aroma and flavor full of smooth roasted malt, light vanilla, light Christmas spice and a touch of coffee. Very smooth and drinkable. Not overwhelming.

Bottle from Timfoolery, Roasty, vanilla is hidden, which I appreciate, great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from HF trade. Aroma and flavor of sweet, light roast, vanilla, and slight cinnamon. Nice palate after a few sips. Good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500mL bottle from JMRSN. Thanks! Because nothing says summer like a winter porter.

A: Do you like some head? Because this pour fills about half my glass with a light cappucino foam. Very dark mahogany. Decent legs. Also, the bottle has a single bubble blown out of it like a childs bubble toy. 

N: Coffee, raisin, cola, chocolate, caramel, and vanilla. Theres some blackberry mixed in here as well.

T: Very, very bitter/earthy with a lot of cinnamon spice. Theres a decent amount of sweetness here. Very, very assertive.

M: Maybe a touch light given the ABV, but the carbonation is pleasant and its got a good chalkiness. 

O: A pretty nice beer that Id probably have again. The cinnamon balance here works, however, I think this combination works better in a stout.

11th June 2013Tasting at Bruces pad. Thanks to Leighton who always comes up with the Hill Farmstead treats! Opaque black - brown beer, good tan head. Palate is airy and a little soft. Fairly dry. Mellow dark malts, just a touch of roast and coffee. Mild roast bitterness develops but is offsett by vanilla and a trace of wood. Dry and mildly bitter finish. Not the smoothest of Hill Farmstead beers but pretty drinkable.

Bottle, many thanks to Leighton. It pours darkest brown (near black) with a medium light tan head. The nose is roasted malt, pine, caramel, chocolate, mild coffee, cocoa and ash. The taste is roasted malt, toast, earth, coffee, cocoa, light spice, touch of dark fruit and decent bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Not a whole lot of depth to it. Decent for sure, but not up to the regular high standards of HF.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2013 Bottle at Jacks farewell at Bruces. Big thanks to Leighton. I finally get to try my first pure Hill Farm. Pours pitch black with a big, thick & creamy beige head, loads of lacing. Nose is quite robust and roasty. Some dark fruits mingle with heavy milk chocolate and espresso notes. Kind of like a Tim Tam. Taste is heavy chocolate biscuit, machiatto and cream with a touch of cinnamon but not overly. Creamy mouth feel with a bitter lasting finish. Touch warming on the end. A very solid Porter

Bottle. Cheers To Leighton for supplying this! Whats with the garbage photo on this page? Anyway, deep brown with a large head. The nose is coffee, milk chocolate. Burnt brown sugar. The taste is dominated by earthy roasted dark malts. Some spice, nutmeg. Pepper. Chocolate and coffee cake. Medium body, fine carbonation. Overall, quite good, but not a standout in HFs generally exemplary lineup.
Brown/black pour with foamy tan head and lace. Coffee and roasted malt aroma. Sweet chocolate, roasted malt, and a good malt bitter. Medium body with good carbonation. A very nice beer.

50cl bottle pours a watery but opaque black with some creamy, off white head.  Nose is very nice, coffee grounds, coffee with cream, light vanilla bean, malt, molasses.  Flavor is very nice too, more coffee than the nose lets on, cola, vanilla, malt, light toast, molasses, chocolate cake.  Medium bodied, dry chocolate finish.

Bottle tx to Sean. Pours black with a big creamy tanned head leaving lacing. Aroma is roasted coffee acidy ashy dry some chocolate a bit fruity. Flavor is a bit sweet vinous roasted coffee dark chocolate pleasantly bitter, nicely balanced full of flavors. Longlived good bitter roasted chocolate finish.

Bottle thanks to Hopscotch. Dark brown pour with a mocha head. Dark roasted malt and coffee aromas. Fantastic mouthfeel with a very good body. Very complex with rich dark roasted malts, vanilla, and mild expresso notes.  Undercurrents of muted caramel and bakers chocolate.  Damn fine coffee porter.

Pour is black and opaque, tons of tight caramel brown head. Nose is roasted coffee, assertive vanilla and rich chocolate, light char, fair spice to it.  Taste is similar in comparison to the nose. Same aspects, coffee is light with the roast slightly stronger.  Very rich chocolate and vanilla, light peppery tang to it. Balanced sweetness subtly behind showing a deep malt presence. Body is lighter, carb is assertive with a juicy texture and semi dry finish.

500 ml bottle via STLHops trade. Pours a deep, dark, mostly opaque brown with a big fizzy tan head. Rich roasted and toasted malts, dark chocolate, and the coffee, cinnamon, and vanilla beans are all so, so subtle. Maybe I sat on it too long - Fall/Winter 2012 vintage - for those to really pop. But it didnt matter because the thing is so well done otherwise. Medium-bodied and roasty, with medium carbonation. A step down from Everett, but a slight one.
Apr. 23, 2013. Near-black, sedimentary pour yields a powerful explosion of chewy, chalky, dark-chocolate, spicy, mocha flavor. Dessert-in-a glass; finest porter Ive yet tried. Highly recommended.

A - pours opaque black with very low caramel brown fluffy head. S - oatmealy stoutish. Earthy, chalk, bittersweet chocolate, cocoa powder,  oak notes, vegetal malts. Light tangy notes. M - watery light medium body. Bitter and dry. Strong up front to a flat end. T - bittersweet chocolate, toasted oak, earth, chalk, sweet molasses to a simple dry bitter end. Notes of mineral water. Grassy hop notes. O - simple porter, chocolately and not much else. 3.7

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Thanks to mike12da. Good medium coffee, some cream, and dark bready notes. Pitch black, small tan head, some good lace. Coffee is the main note in initial (and unlike so many coffee brews, the stuff wasnt overboiled) / more smooth coffee and some light chocolate in mid / finishes creamy and chocolaty. Medium heavy. A pleasant and well-made porter.
Bottled. Nose of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla. Black with lace. Soft, low carbonation. Mellow and nice.

Deep black .. Mild foam .. Mild spice, oak, and tar .. Easy mouth .. Good but below HFs usual mind blowing standard

bottle to pizza port strong ale snifter poured a jet black slicky oil wounderland 
since it was shared it had a little tan head it lased the glass aftrer sip 
strong cinnamon nose leather wood some coffee taste was robust with vanilla this beer was out of hand i wish i had a case

bottle shared by jean-michaël, thanks! pours black with an almost creamy beige head, good retention and lacing. roastiness-plenty, some residual burnt caramel sugars, some lactose notes. underlying coffee and a unique spice blend - very well blended, in fact. medium body - oily, average carbonation, nice coffee-grassy finish. doesnt beat everett but sure is good and, as always, very well executed by HF.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with medium creamy beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, fruits, coffee. Taste is of roasted malt, fruits, coffee. Palate: Medium-full bodied. Overall: Very good.

Bottle shared at RBWGl 
Pours black with a thin tan head.
Rich malty aroma.
The flavor is rich and malty, near perfect.
Delightful complex brew.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2013 Bottle... Pours dark brown with an insignificant head that quickly dissipates. The luxuriant bouquet offers a swirl of mocha, fudge, toasted nuts, vanilla and a nuance of lightly smoked malt. Barely medium-bodied with a thin mouthfeel and vibrant carbonation. The flavor is a mélange of sweet mocha, fudge and mild, tannic bitterness that is buffered by a delicate note of  vanilla. Finishes mildly bitter and roasty. Pours jet black with a thick mocha head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roast and hops. Taste is bitter chocolate and roast. Nice thick mouthfeel. Really tasty, prob my favorite in this style.

Bottle shared at RBWG, thanks to Leighton I think.   Pours dark brown/basically black a frothy yellow white head.  Nose is sweet initially with vanilla up front, some roast,  coffee, light cocoa, cinnamon and spices.  Flavor is similar, spices are tame and balance well with the roast and thank god the vanilla is controlled. Glad I finally got to try this one.

Black pour with a tan head. Big roasted malt and vanilla aromas. Plenty of coffee, a bit of ash, dark chocolate, and a little bit of spice. The flavor is quite roasty and a little bit bitter. Tons of vanilla, a mild molasses sweetness, and big coffee. Dark chocolate, a bit of ash, and some spice.

Bottle shared amongst friends. Was super jazzed to finally land a bottle of this. Good amount of coffee grind aroma but was hoping for a little more cinnamon to come through. I was serving this at practically room temperature so Im pretty certain it wasnt that. It was a great drinking experience, but it didnt blow me away.

Bottled split with a buddy and poured into a Drakes snifter.Pours black, looks a little thin with a small tan head. Smells roasty, spicy with a soft coffee presence. The taste is a pretty balanced between roast, and smooth coffee with light carbonation. Mouth feel is a little thin, with some oily vanilla backbone. Nothing overwhelming here. The taste has a small spice factor, but overall the taste is pretty clean. A really nice and balanced porter show casing a few different flavors that go a long way. Very nicely done.

Bottle shared at RBWG 2013 
Appearance: Black with a medium sized tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts and chocolate 
Taste: Roasted malts, vanilla and chocolate 
Nice and tasty

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours black with a lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, and some light hops.  Flavor the same, with a nice blend of everything.  Smooth texture.  A great porter.

Pours a rich burnt umber color with a fluffy sticky eggshell foam. The nose is pretty direct with nice roasted chocolate, soft vanilla, spent coffee grounds, warming spices and some antique earthy malt character. The palate follows the nose nicely with big upfront roast character that falls quickly into a smooth creamy yet still well carbonated midpalate. Nice rich chocolate cake notes mingle with an earthy coffee bitterness and soft vanilla bean finish. Nice soft lingering finish... Yum.
Really nice porter. Lots of chocolate. Rich, almost more of a stout than a porter.
Bottle shared at the Santa Cruz tasting in January. Big coffee notes, firm roastiness balanced by sweet dark malts. Smooth vanilla bean finish.

Refrigerated brown 500 mL botted served in a snifter.  Pours black with dark brown highlights and beige head.  Little lacing, medium/thin body, low carbonation, and sightly tart roasted malt.    Taste is slightly tart dark malt and tart cherry.

Poured from a 500 ml bottle thanks to lukaduke. Aroma is roasty oats with a vanilla and subtle tartness in the background. Taste has a roasty sweetness with a dry, green apple tartness in the finish. Interesting take on the style.

Black pour with thin brown lacing. Coffee, smoke, oak, earthiness, hints of vanilla and spice. Smooth, medium-bodied, a little too much carbonation, and finishes bitter. 


Not sure if its just this bottle, but I was getting a persistent metallic taste throughout.

Bottle brought to Tim/Bills for Alens birthday tasting. Split with 5-6 heads. Pours a pitch black with small coffee head. Aromas and flavor of wood, mollases, perfect amt of roast, earth and light vanilla. One of the most balanced and drinkable porters I have had to date. Medium to fuller bodied. Another winner from Seany Hill.

This poured a medium brown color with a beige cover.  Aroma was vanilla, spices, chocolate, mild roast, and earthy hops.  Flavor was very well balanced, nice mixed bitterness of earthy hops and roast, with just enough sweetness to keep it from being a black ipa.
(500ml bottle) medium brown, lasting tan bubbles. Nose of to h chocolate, graham cracker, cream, bakers chocolate, dry. Taste of dry chocolate, rich, light barrel. Dry body, medium thickness.

750 mL growler served in a HF wine glass.

Pours a rich chocolate black with a quickly dissipating mocha head. Dots of lacing and wet legs line the glass. Aroma starts with mild smoke, bread and burnt malt, and turns mildly sweet with molasses, milk chocolate, vanilla bean and light cream. Flavor has a bready and coffee base, more roasted malt and a bakers chocolate finish that isnt particularly sweet. Vanilla and molasses subtly blend in and out of the body without ever being cloying. Biggest knock on this is the slightly thin body and watery finish. Nowhere as robust as Everett and too thin for the style and ABV for my taste. Regardless, an excellent, unique porter but Ill just stick to Everett.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2013 Pours dark black coffee in color with a creamy darker beige head. The aroma brings sweet vanilla and coffee blended so well with a tinge of chocolate. The flavor brings a lot of coffee and ends with pleasant bitter roasted malts all on a creamy body.

From bottle from brewery. Aroma is coffee, caramel, and a good heaping of vanilla. Color is dark brown, nearly black with minimal tan head. Very sweet with toffee like taste and very distinct vanilla. Full bodied, slick texture, with a long finish of coffee, a little bit of chocolate, and vanilla.

Aroma: vanilla, rich chocolate, notes of roast and coffee, dark sugars.  Pours black, nearly opaque, tan head with average retention and spotty lacing.  Flavor: chocolate and vanilla, smooth roast profile, a touch of coffee, caramel and molasses, coffee, rather faint cinnamon.  Bitterness is low-medium, but balances the malt nicely.  Medium-full body, medium carbonation, very smooth and drinkable.  Great brew.

500 ml bottle shared by Forgetfu (thanks Bill!) poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, light earthiness and light cinnamon. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla, coffee and light cinnamon with a smooth lingering chocolate finish.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, huge thanks to Bill! Dark thick black pour, tan head, aroma has big notes of vanilla, smoke, hints of roast, coffee, cinnamon, spice, slight chocolate, caramel, toffee, finishing fairly sweet, nicely spicy.  Taste is a real nice mix of caramel, molasses, toffee, hints of earth, nice coffee, green espresso bean, the cinnamon works so well with the vanilla, slight chocolate and brownie notes, finishing fairly sweet.  This is so well crafted.

Bottle @ Ratmans house. Thanks forgetfu! Pours a deep brown/black appearance with a dark brown head. Spicy cinnamon, huge vanilla bean, rich dark chocolate, cocoa, mildly roasty aroma. Big chocolate, cocoa, roasty coffee, big vanilla flavor. Delicious stuff.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is rich toasted malt. Taste is medium lots if nuts and chocolate. Some vanilla

Bottle. Pours black with little head. The aroma is very malty. The taste is malty as well and very smooth. Finishes with a little smokiness to it.
